listChange.change: (Luca Giovannini) Fixed speaker tags and particDesc.

div.p: A COMEDY, As it was presented by her Majesties Servants, at the private House in Drury Lane.

Written by
George Chapman,
and James Shirly.
LONDON, Printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. 1639.

div.head: Actus Primus.
div.stage: Enter Sr. Marmaduke Travers, and Mr. Bostocke.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.p: WHether so fast Sr. Marmaduke, a word.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My honorable blood? wod I could stay
To give thee twentie, I am now engag'd
To meete a noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Or rather
A Gentlewoman, let her alone, and goe
With me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Ile shew thee a Lady of fire.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: A Lady of the Lake were not so dangerous.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I meane a spirit in few words, because
I love thee, Ile be open. I am going
To see my Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Ile dispence with my
Occasion to see a hansome Lady,
I know you'le chuse a rare one.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She is a creature
Worth admiration, such a beauty, wit,
And an estate besides, thou canst not chuse
But know her name, the Lady Lucina.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Mine, whose but mine?
Am I not nobly borne, does not my blood
Deserve her?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: To tell you truth, I was now going thither,
Though I pretended an excuse, and with
A Complement from one that is your rivall.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Does she love any body else?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I know not,
But shee has halfe a score upon my knowledge
Are sutors for her favour.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Name but one,
And if he cannot shew as many coates.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: He thinkes he has good cards for her, and likes
His game well.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Be an understanding Knight,
And take my meaning, if he cannot shew
As much in Heraldry.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I doe not know how rich he is in fields,
But he is a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Is he a branch of the Nobilitie,
How many Lords can he call cozen? else
He must be taught to know he has presum'd
To stand in competition with me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You shall pardon me,
I have that within me must not be provok'd,
There be some living now that ha beene kill'd
For lesser matters.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Some living that ha beene kill'd!

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I meane some living that ha seene examples,
Not to confront Nobilitie, and I
Am sensible of my honour.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: His name is
Sr. Ambrose.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Lamount a Knight of yesterday,
And he shall die to morrow, name another.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Not so fast Sir. you must take some breath.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I care no more for killing halfe a dozen
Knights of the lower house, I meane that are not
Descended from Nobilitie, then I doe
To kicke any footeman, and Sr. Ambrose were
Knight of the Sunne, King Oberon should not save him,
Nor his Queene Mab.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Sr. Ambrose
How does thy Knighthood? ha.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: My Nimph of honour well, I joy to see thee.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Sr. Marmaduke tells me thou art sutor to
Lady Lucina.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I have ambition
To be her servant.

sp.speaker: Bos.
sp.l: Hast, thar't a brave Knight, and I commend
Thy judgement.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Sr Marmaduke himselfe leanes that way too.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Why didst conceale it, come, the more the merrier,
But I could never see you there.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I hope
Sir we may live.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Ile tell you Gentlemen,
Cupid has given us all one Livery,
I serve that Lady too, you understand me,
But who shall carry her, the fates determine,
I could be knighted too.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: That would be no addition to
Your blood.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I thinke it would not, so my Lord told me,
Thou know'st my Lord, not the Earle, my tother
Cozen, theres a sparke his predecessors
Have match'd into the blood, you understand
He put me upon this Lady, I proclaime
No hopes, pray lets together Gentlemen;
If she be wise, I say no more, shee shanot
Cost me a sigh, nor shall her love engage me
To draw a sword, I ha vow'd that.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Twere pitty that one drop
Of your Heroicke blood should fall toth' ground,
Who knowes but all your cozen Lords may die.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: As I beleeve them not immortall sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Then you are gulfe of honour swallow all,
May marry some Queene your selfe, and get Princes
To furnish the barren parts of Christendome.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Sir Marmaduke in private? my Lady wod
Speake with you.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Tis her servant, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I hope he is not sent for.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: But come alone, I shall be troubled
With their inquiries, but Ile answer 'em.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: My Lady would speake with you sir.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Not too loude, I was troubled with Sr. Marmaduke.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I doe not like this whispering,

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Forget not the time, and to come alone.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: My businesse is to you sir, these
Kept me off, my Lady Lucina
Has a great minde to speake with you,
Little doe these imagine how she honours me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: If I faile, may the Surgeon
When he opens the next veine, let out all my honorable blood,
There's for thy paines, what thou shalt be hereafter
Time shall declare, but this must be conceal'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: No, no I have no cause, you smile Sr. Ambrose.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: But of our file, another of her suitors.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: My honored Knights, and men of lustie kindred.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Morrow to all Gentlemen, Ile tell you
Who is return'd?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: A friend of ours that went to travell.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I saw him within these three minuts, and know not how I
Lost him agen, he's not farre off, dee keepe a Catalogue
Of your debts.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Such dulnesse in your memory, there was
About sixe moneths ago a Gentleman
That was perswaded to sell all his land,
And to put the money out most wisely,
To have for one at his returne from Venice,
The shotten Herring, is hard by.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Iacke Freshwater, Ile not see him yet.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: It will be for your honour, marry wee
Without much staine, may happily compound,
And pay him nothing.
sp.stage: Enter Freshwater, and Mounsieur Le Friske.
sp.l: Here comes the thing
With what formalitie he treades, and talkes,
And manageth a toothpicke like a Statesman.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Ile not bid him welcome home.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Whats the tother Rat thats with him?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Dee not know him, tis the Court dancing Weesill.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: A meere French footeman Sir, does he not looke
Like a thing come off oth' Saltsellar.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A Dancer?
I would allow him gay about the legges,
But why his body should exceede decorum,
Is a sinne oth' state.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Thats all.
I can informe you of their dance in Italy,
Marry that very morning I left Venice,
I had intelligence of a new device.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Si Signior, I know not
What countryman invented, but they say
There be Chopinoes made with such rare art,
That worne by a Lady when she meanes to dance,
Shall with their very motion sound forth musicke,
And by a secret sympathy with their tread
Strike any tune that without other instrument,
Their feete both dance and play.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Your lodging Mounsieur,
That when I have leasure I may dare
Present an humble servitor.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I do ly
At the signe of Dona Margaretta de Pia
In the Strand.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: At the Magget a Pie in the Strand sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: At de Magdepie boon adieu serviteur. Exit.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Ile speake to him,
Yare welcome home sir.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: He wonot know me, this is excellent,
He shall be acquainted better, ere I part
With any sommes.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Next time weele not know him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Would all my creditors had this blessed ignorance.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Now Coronell I'le take my leave.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I shall meete you anon,
I am to waite upon a cosin of mine.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: My Lord? Enter Lord Rainebow and Barker.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Your Lordship honours me in this acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Yare not a proclamation that every man is bound to take notice on,
And I cannot tell who you are by instinct.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Coronell? your humble servant, harke you Franke.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You are acquainted with my Lord then,
Is he not a compleate Gentleman? his family
Came in with the Conqueror.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: You had not else beene kinne to him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: A poore slip, a syens from that honourable tree.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: He is the Ladies Idoll, they ha not leasure
To say their prayers for him, a great advancer
Of the new Ball.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Nay hee's right, right as my legge Coronell.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: But tother Gentleman you doe not know his inside.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I ha seene him, he lookes philosophicall.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Who! hee's the wit, whom your Nobilitie
Are much oblig'd to for his company,
He has a railing genious, and they cherish it,
Fling dirt in every face when hee's ith' humour,
And they must laugh, and thanke him, he is dead else.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Or lose their mirth, hee's knowne in every science,
And can abuse em all, some ha suppos'd
He has a worme ins braine, which at some time
Oth' Moone doth ravish him into perfect madnesse,
And then he prophesies, and will depose
The Emperor, and set up Bethalem Gabre.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Hee's dead, I hope he wonot conjure for him.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: His father shanot scape him nor his ghost,
Nor heaven, nor hell, his jest must ha free passage,
Hee's gone, and I lose time to talke on him,
Farewell,
Your Countesse
May expect too long,
Farewell Coronell. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lady Rosomond, and Lady Honoria.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Why doe you so commend him?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Does he not
Deserve it? name a gentleman in the Kingdome,
So affable, so moving in his language,
So pleasant, witty, indeede every thing
A Lady can desire.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Sure thou dost love him,
Ile tell his Lordshippe when I see him agen,
How zealous you are in his commendation.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If I be not mistaken, I have heard
Your tongue reach higher in his praises Madam,
How ere you now seeme cold, but if you tell him
My opinion, as you shall doe him no pleasure,
You can doe me no injury, I know
His Lordship has the constitution
Of other Courtiers, they can endure
To be commended.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: But I prethee tell me,
Is not love whence this proceeds, I have
I must confesse discourst of his good parts,
Desir'd his company.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You are not I hope jealous,
If I should say all night I neede not blush,
It was but at a Ball, but what of this?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I hope you ha no patent
To dance alone with him, if he ha priviledge
To kisse another Lady, she may say
He does salute her, and returne a cursie
To shew her breeding, but Ile now be playner,
Although you love this Lord, it may possible
He may dispose his thoughts another way.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Who can helpe it, he has eyes
To looke on more than one, and understand
Perhaps to guide, and place his love upon
The most deserving object.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Most deserving,
This language is not levill with that friendship,
You have profest, this touches a comparison.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why doe you thinke all excellence is throng'd
Within your beauty.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You are angry Lady,
How much does this concerne you to be thus
Officious in his cause, if you be not
Engag'd by more than ordinary affection.
I must interpret this no kinde respect
To me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Good Madam why? because,
I thinke, and tell you that another Lady
May be as hansome in some mans opinion,
Admit I lov'd him too, may not I hold
Proportion with you, on some entreaty.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: They're loude, Ile not be seene yet.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What is it that exalts you above all
Comparison? my father was as good
A gentleman, and my mother has as great
A spirit.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Twill appeare
No greater miracle in me I take it,
Yet difference will be, perhaps I may
Affect him with a better consequence.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Your consequence perhaps may be denied too,
Why there are no such wonders in your eye
Which other composition doe not boast of,
My Lord no doubt hath in his travells clapt
As modest cheekes, and kist as melting lippes.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: And yet mine are not pale.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: It may be they blush for the teeth behinde them.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I have read
No sonnets on the sweetnesse of your breath.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: But I have heard of your tongue exalted much,
Highly commended.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not above your forehead,
When you have brush'd away the hairie pentehrush,
And made it visible.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ile now interrupt 'em.
Theyle fall by the eares else presently.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Expresse it in discoverie of that
Made you so earnest, I am confident
You were not practising a Dialogue
To entertaine me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Do not you blush, fie Madam.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay and you come to blush once, and fie Madam,
Ile know the secret, by this kisse I will,
And this.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You were kis'd first, discover now
At your discretion.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: My Lord we were in jest.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It might ha turn'd to earnest, if your Lordship
Had not interpos'd.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: About a man ith' world, you are best name him.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: You have the better gift at telling secrets.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Yet agen, come Ile helpe it out, there is
A gentleman ith' world, some call a Lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay nay, you must stand too't,
One, whom you
Love, it will appeare no greater miracle
In you I take it, one no doubt that hath
Travel'd, and clapt as modest cheekes, and kis'd
As melting lippes, thus farre ime right, but what
Name this most happy man doth answer too,
Is not within my circle.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Not to retaine your Lordship ith' darke,
Confident you'le not accuse my modesty
For giving you a truth, you shall not travell
Beyond your selfe to find his name, but doe not
Triumph my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Am I so fortunate,
Then love I doe forgive thee, and will cherish
The flame I did suspect would ruine me,
You two divide my love, onely you two,
Be gentle in your Empire heavenly Ladies,
No enemy abroad can threaten you,
Be carefull then, that you maintaine at home
No civill warres.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: You are pleas'd to smile upon me gentle Lady,
And I have tooke it in my heart more than
Imaginary blessings with what pleasure
Could I behold this beautie, and consume
My understanding to know nothing else,
My memory to preserve no other figure.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: My Lord, I am not worth your flatterie.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I flatter you? Venus her selfe be judge,
To whom you are so like in all thats faire,
Twere sinne but to be modest.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Do not mistake me, twere
A sinne but to be modest in your praises,
Heres a hand, nature shew me such another,
A brow, a cheeke, a lip, and every thing,
Happy am I that Cupids blinde.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: If he could see, he would forsake his Mistresse
To be my rivall, and for thy embraces
Be banish'd heaven.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: My Lord Ile take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: If you did know how great a part of me,
Will whither in your absence, you would have
More charitie, one accent of unkinde
Language from you, doth wound me more than all
The mallice of my destinies, oh deare Madam,
You say you'le take your leave of your poore servant;
Say rather, you will dwell for ever here,
And let me stay and gaze upon
Your heavenly forme.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I can be patient
To heare your Lordship mocke me, these are but
A course reward for my good thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: This tis to use plaine dealing, and betray the inside
Of our hearts to women, did you thinke well of me
So late, and am I forfeited already,
Am I a Christian?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Make me not miserable then, deare Madam,
With your suspition, I dissemble with you,
But you know too well what command your beauty
Has upon me.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Give me leave
My Lord to wonder you can love me,
With such a flame you have exprest yet shee,
Your mistresse?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I like not this so well.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: There is no way but one to make me happy.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I wish my Lord I had the art to effect
What you desire.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: It is within
Your powers.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Since it is so
That Ime not able to determine which
My heart, so equall unto both, would chuse,
My suite is to your vertues, to agree
Betweene your selves, whose creature I shall be,
You can judge better of your worths than I,
My allegiance shall be ready if you can
Conclude which shall ha the supremacie;
Take pitty on your servant gentle Ladies,
And reconcile a heart too much divided,
So with the promise of my obedience
To her that shall be fairest, wisest, sweetest
Of you two, when I next present a lover,
I take distracted leave. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Why, this is worse than all the rest.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Hee's gone,
And has referr'd himselfe to us.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: This will
Aske counsell.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And some time I would be loth
To yeeld.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: And I, Cupid instruct us both. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Secundus.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: ANd what made you to undertake this voyage,
Sweete Signior Freshwater.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: An affection
I had to be acquainted with some countries.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And you returne fraught home with the rich devices,
Fashions of steeples, and the situations
Of galouses, and wit no doubt a bushell,
What price are Oates in Venice?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Signior
I kept no horses there, my man, and I

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Give him good words, a Poxe take him.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Which I reduc'd into a narrow compasse,
Some call it selling.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: He would sell bargaines of a childe.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: It was but two hundred pound Per annum sir,
A loane revenew.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: And did you sell it all?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I did not leave an acre, rod, or perch,
That had beene no discretion, when I was selling
I would sell to purpose, doe you see this roll,
I have good securitie for my money sir,
Not an egge here but has five chickens in't,
I did most pollitickely disburse my summes,
To have five for one at my returne from Venice,
And now I thanke my starres I am at home.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And so by consequence in three moneths your estate
Will be five times as much or quintupled.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yes Signior quintupled,
I wonot purchase yet I meane to use
This tricke seaven yeares together, first
Ile still put out, and quintuplie as you call't,
And when I can in my Exchequer tell
Two, or three Millions, I will fall a purchasing.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I have a minde to buy
Constantinople from the Turke, and give it
The Emperour.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: What thinke you of Ierusalem?
If you would purchase that, and bring it nearer,
The Christian Pilgrimes would be much oblig'd to yee,
When did you wash your sockes?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Then tis your breath, to your lodging, and perfume it,
You'le tell the sweeter lies to them that will
Lose so much time to aske about your travell,
You wonot sell your debts?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Have you as much left in ready cash as will
Keepe you and this old troule a fortnight longer,
Die, and forgive the world, thou maist be buried,
And ha the Church-cloth, if you can put in
Securitie, the Parish shall be put
To no more charge, dost thou hope to have a penny
Of thy owne money backe, is this an age
Of five for one, die ere the towne takes notice,
There is a hidious woman carries ballets,
And has a singing in her head, take heed
And hang thy selfe, thou maist not heare the time,
You remember Coriate.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Wee'le ha more verses o'thy travells Coxcombe,
Bookes shall be sold in bushells in Cheape side,
And come in like the Pescods, waine loads full
Of thee, and thy man Apple Iohn that lookes
As he had beene a senight in the straw
A ripening for the market, farewell Rusiting,
Thou art not worth my spleene, doe not forget
My counsell, hang thy selfe, and thou go'st off
Without a Sessions. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Fine, Ime glad hee's gone, Gudgine, what dost thou thinke.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: I thinke y'are well rid of railing Madcap.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nay, nay hee'le not spare a Lord
But were not I best call in my moneyes Gudgin,
My estate wonot hold out, I must be more
Familiar with my gentlemen. Enter Lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Was it not Franke Barker that parted from you?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: There is a summe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: There was a summe my Lord delivered
From your poore servant Freshwater.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I remember,
But I have businesse now, come, home to me,
The monie's safe, you were to give me five
For one at your returne.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I five? Your Lordship has forgot the Cinquepace.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Something it is, but when I am at leasure
We will discourse of that, and of your travell,
Farewell Signior. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Ist come to this? if Lords play fast and loose,
What shall poore Knights, and gentlemen?
Hum, tis he. Enter Coronell.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: A Poxe upon him, what makes he in my way.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: A wy, Ie ne pa parlee Anglois,
There were five English peeces.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Ie ne parle Anglois, me speake no word English,
Votre seviteur. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Adiew five peeces,
Gudgin gape, ist not he?
They wonot use me o'this fashion,
Did he not speake to me ith' morning?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I thinke so,
But then you would not know him in Italian,
And now he will not know you in French.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Call you this selling of land, and putting out money
To multiply estate?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: To quintuply five for one, large interest.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Five for one, tis tenne to one if I get my principall.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Your roll is not at the bottome, yet try the rest.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I met him opportunely after all the rest,
And told him how much it would concerne
His livelihood to make haste.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: He must not be seene yet, you know where
To attend for him, give him accesse by
The garden to my chamber, and bring
Me nimbly knowledge when he is there.

div.stage: Enter the Dancer, Lady Rosomond, Lady Lucina, and Lady Honoria.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Very well an dat be skirvy you run trot, trot, trot,
Pisha, follow me, fout Madame, can you not tell
So often learning Madam you foot it now
Pla it ill. Another Lady dances.
Excellent, better den excellent pishaw you be laughed
When you come to do Ball; I teach tree hundred, never
Forgot so much, me sweat taking paine, and fidling Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Purquoy for telling you
Dance not well, you commit fat, and beate me for my
Dilligence becar you dance your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No Mounsieure Le Friske put not up your pipe, my Lady
Was but in jest, and you must take it for a favour.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I veare no favours in dat place, should any gentleman
Of England give me blow, diable me teach him French Passage.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Nay you shanot be so angry, I must have a Coronte,
Pray Madam be reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Sorre, tat is too much par ma foy, I kisse tat white hand,
Give me one two tree buffets, aller, aller looke up your
Countenance, your English man spoile you, he no teach
You looke up, pishaw, carry your body in the swimming
Fashion, and deu allei moy moselle ha, ha, ha,
So for boon excellent becar. Dance.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay a Country dance Scutilla, you are idle,
You know we must be at the Ball anon, come.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Where is the Ball this night.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Oh he dance finely becar, he deserve the Ball of de world,
Fine, fine gentleman, your oder men dance lop, lop with
De lame legge as they want crushes begore, and looke for
Argent in the ground pishaw,
sp.stage: They dance a new Country Dance.
sp.l: Hah, hah, for boone.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Now Madame we take our leave.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ile recompence this kind visite: does your coach stay?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Yes Madam,
Your Ladiship will be too much troubled.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: I have more Ladie, my Schollers.

sp.speaker: Sciu.
sp.p: Is that the way of your instrument.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: All a murdu France, fit, fit adiew
Madam votre serviteur,
Adiew demy Mounsieur. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: The tim's too narrow to discourse at large,
But I intend you a service,
You have deserv'd it
In your owne noblenesse to one I call a kinsman,
Whose life without your charitie had beene
Forfeit to his generalls anger, twas not
Without his cause you after quit your regiment.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: He was my friend, forget it.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: You were sent for
By the Lady Lucina.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Twas my desire to prepare you for
The entertainement, be but pleas'd to obscure
Your selfe behind these hangings a few minuts,
I heare her, you may trust me.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Without dispute, I obey you Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Now Scutilla we are ripe, and ready
To entertaine my Gamesters, my man said
They promised all to come, I was afraid
These Ladies in their kinde departure wo'd not
Bequeath me opportunitie, and the mirth
Doth in the imagination so ticle me,
I wo'd not willingly ha lost it for a Jewell
Of some valew.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If they hold their affections, and keepe touch,
Weele ha some sport. Enter Solomon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Away Scutilla, and
Laugh not loud betweene our acts, weele meete
Agen like musicke, and make our selves merry.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sr. Markmaduke I thought I should have had
Your visite without a summonds.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Lady you gave
One feather to the wings I had before,
Can there be at last a service to imploy
Your creature?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Something hath pleaded for you in your absence.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Oh let me dwell upon your hand, my starres
Have then remembred me agen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How doe the Fennes?
Goes the draning forward, and your Iron Mills?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Draning, and Iron Mills? I know not Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come, you conceale your industry, and care
To thrive, you neede not be so close to me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: By this hand Lady, have I any Iron Mills?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am abus'd else, nay I doe love
One that has Wind-mills in his head.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Projects, and Proclamations, did not you
Travell to Yarmouth to learne how to cast
Brasse buttons, nay I like it, it is an age
For men to looke about 'em, shall I trust
My estate to one that has no thrift, a fellow
But with one face? my husband shall be a Ianus,
He cannot looke too many wayes, and is
Your patent for making Vineger confirm'd:
What a face you put upon't nay, nere dissemble,
Come I know all, you'le thanke that friend of yours,
That satisfied my inquirie of your worth
With such a welcome character, but why
Doe I betray my selfe so fast? beshrow
His commendations.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: How is this? some body
That meant me well, and knew her appetite
To wealth hath told this of me, Ile make use ont;
Well Madam, I desir'd these things more private
Till something worth a mine, which I am now
Promoving had beene perfect to salute you,
But I perceive you hold intelligence
In my affaires, which I interpret love,
And Ile requite it, will you be content
Be a countesse for the present.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I shall want
No honour in your love.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A licence, and say no more,
How blest am I, doe not blush,
I wonot kisse your lip, till I ha brought it. Exit

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Yes Madam you have kept your word,
The Knights transported, gone
To prepare things for the wedding.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How didst thou like the Iron Mills.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: And the Brasse buttons rarely, have you devices
To jeere the rest.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: All the regiment on 'em, or Ile breake my bowstrings.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Away, and let the Swallow enter.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why Sirra, did I command you give accesse to none?
But Sr. Ambrose Lamount?
Whom you know I sent for,
Audacious Groome.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is Sr. Ambrose Coxcombe, is it not,
Cry mercy noble sir, I tooke you muffled
For one that every day sollicites me
To bestow my little dogge upon him, but you'r welcome,
I thinke I sent for you.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: It is my happinesse
To waite your service Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I heare say you have vow'd to die a Batchellor,
I hope it is not true sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And that you'le turne religious Knight.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I turne religious Knight, who has abus'd me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I would onely know the truth, it were great pittie,
For my owne part I ever wish'd you well,
Although in modesty I have beene silent,
Pray what's a clocke?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I had a dreame last night, me thought I saw you
Dance so exceedingly rarely, that I fell
In love.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: My legge is at your service to come over.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I wondred at my selfe, but I considered,
That many have beene caught with hansome faces,
So my love grew.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What followed in my dreame
I ha forgot.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Since the morning
I finde some alteration, you know
I have told you twenty times I would not love you,
But whether twere your wisedome or your fate
You would not be satisfied, now I know not
If something were procur'd, what I should answer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Would were my estate were doubled.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You have not Purchas'd since you fell in love?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Revells have beene some charge to you, you were ever
A friend to Ladies, pitty but he should rise
By one, has fallen with so many, had you not
A head once?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: A head? I have one still.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Of haire I meane,
Favours ha glean'd too much, pray pardon me
If it were mine, they should goe looke their bracelets,
Or stay till the next crop, but I blush sir
To hold you in this discourse, you will perhaps
Conster me in a wrong sence; but you may use
Your owne discretion till you know me better,
Which is my soules ambitions.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Cunning Gipsie shee'le use me thus too
When I come too't?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Lady I know your mind, when I see you next. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Youle see me agen, ha ha ha, Scutilla.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Here Madam almost dead with stifling my laughter,
Why hee's gone for a Licence, you did injoyne him no Silence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I wou'd have 'em all meete and brag o'their severall
Hopes they wonot else be sensible, and quit me o'their
Tedious visitation, who's next?
I would the Coronell were come,
I long to have about with him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Retire, and give the lay admittance.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Madam, I kisse your faire hand.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Two not become your birth, and blood to stoope
To such a title.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I must confesse deare Lady,
I carry in my veines more precious honour
Then other men, blood of a deeper crimson,
But you shall call me any thing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not I sir,
It would not become me to change your title,
Although I must confesse I could desire
You were lesse honourable.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Why I prethee,
Ist a fault to spring from the Nobilitie?
There be some men have sold well favour'd Lordships,
To be ill favoured Noblemen, and though
I weare no title of the state, I can
Adorne a Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That is my misfortune,
I would you could not sir.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Are you the worse
For that? consider Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have considered,
And I could wish with all my heart you were
Not halfe so noble, nay indeede no Gentlman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay, if you give me leave to speake my thoughts,
I would you were a fellow of two degrees
Beneath a foote man, one that had no kindred,
But Knights oth' post, nay worse, pardon me sir,
In the humour I am in, I wish, and heartily,
You were a sonne oth' people rather then.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Good Madam give me your reason.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Few women wish so ill to whom they love.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: They doe not love like me then.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My wealths a begger, nay the title of
A Lady which my husband left, is a shadow
Compar'd to what you bring to innoble me,
And all the children you will get, but I
Out of my love desire you such a one,
That I might adde to you, that you might be
Created by my wealth, made great by me,
Then should my love appeare, but as you are,
I must receive addition from you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: No body heares, why harke you Lady, could
You love me, if I were lesse honourable?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Honourable? why you cannot be so base
As I would have you, that the world might say
My marriage gave you somewhat.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Say you so,
Vnder the Rose, if that will doe you a pleasure,
The Lords doe call me cosin, but I am.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Not to be lawfull, I came in at the Wicket,
Some call it the Window.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then I preferre you before all my suiters,
Sr. Ambrose Lamount, and Sr. Marmaduke
Travers are all Mountibankes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A Lanse pre sado, how my joy transports me,
But shall I trust to this, doe not you flatter?
Will not you fly from that, and be legitimate,
When we are married, you men are too cunning
With simple Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Doe but marry me,
Ile bring the Midwife.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Say no more, provide
What you thinke necessary, and all shall be
Dispatch'd.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I guesse your meaning, and thus seale
My best devotion. Exit.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Away now and present your selfe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Oh Scutilla, hold me, I shall fall
In peeces else, ha ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Beshrow me Madam, but I wonder
At you, you woond him rarely up.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Have not I choise of precious husbands? now and
The Coronell were here, the taske
Were over.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Then you might goe play,
Madam the Coronell.

sp.speaker: Lue.
sp.p: Is he come once more? withdraw, bid him march hither.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Now is my turne Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yare welcome sir, I thought you would have gone,
And not grac'd me so much as with a poore
Salute at parting.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: She jeares me already, no Lady I'me already
Engag'd to a siege at home, and till that service
Be over, I enquire no new employments.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: A Cittadell,
That severall forces are set downe before,
And all is entrench'd.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Ostend was sooner taken then her fort
Is like to be for any thing I perceive.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Her provision
May faile her, but she is devilish obstinate,
She feares nor fire nor famine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ha ha ha, alas poore Coronell;
If youle take my advice remove your siege,
A province will be sooner wonne in the
Low countries, ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Twas but to tell you my opinion in this businesse,
You'le sooner circumcise the Turkes dominions,
Then take this toy you talke off, I doe know it,
Farewell good Souldier, ha ha ha, and yet tis pittie,
Is there no stratagem, no tricke, no undermine;
If she be given so desperate, your body
Had neede to be well victuall'd, theres a citie
And suburbes in your belly, and you must
Lay in betimes to prevent mutinie
Among the small guts, which with winde of venge else
Will breake your guarde of buttons, ha ha ha
Come weele laugh, and lie downe in the next roome Scutilla.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: So so, I did expect no good,
Why did not I strike her, but Ile doe something,
And be with you to bring before you thinke out,
Mallice and Mercurie assist me. Exit.

div.head: Actus Tertius.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: SO so, yau'e a precious time on't.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Who can helpe it Franke, if Ladies will
Be wilde, repentance tame 'em, for my part
I court not them, till they provoke me toote.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: And doe they both affect you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: So they say,
And did justifie it to my face.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: And you did praise their modesty.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I confesse I prais'd 'em
Both when I saw no remedy.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Do not
Doe not beleeve it my young Lord, theyle make
Fooles of a thousand such, they doe not love you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Why, and shall please your wisedome?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: They are women,
Thats a reason, and may satisfie you,
They cannot love a man.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Themselves,
And all little enough, they have a tricke
To conjure with their eyes, and perhaps raise
A masculine spirit, but lay none.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Good Cato
Be not over-wise now, whats the reason
That women are not sainted in your Calender,
You have no frosty constitution?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Would you were halfe so honest.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Why a woman
May love thee one day.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Yes when I make legges
And faces like such fellowes as you are.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Mounsieur La Friske. Enter Mounsieur La Friske.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Nay Franke thou shalt not goe.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Ile come agen when you ha done your Iygge.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Come you shall sit downe, this fellow will make thee laugh.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I shall laugh at you both, and I stay.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Harke you Mounsieur, this gentleman has a great
Minde to learne to dance.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: He command my service,
Please your Lordship beginne tat he may
See your profit alkey hah.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Well enough for the dogge-dayes, but have
You no other dancing for the Winter, a man
May freeze and walke thus.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: It be all your grace Mounsieur, your
Dance be horseplay begar for de stable not
De chamber, your ground passage hah
Never hurt de backe Mounsieur, nor trouble
De legge mush, hah plait ill you learne
Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: For mirth sake, and thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Begar I teach you presently, dance with all de
Grace of de body for your good, and my profit.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I shall never endure it, pox upon him.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Tis but dis in de beginning, one, two, tree, foure, five, the
Cinquepace, alley Mounsieur, stand upright an begar.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Let him set you in toth posture.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: My broder my Lord know wel for de litle kit he fiddle
And me for de posture of de body, begar de King has no too
Sush subjects hah, dere be one foote, two foote, have
You tree foote, begar you have more den I have den.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: One, beene two hah, you goe to fast, you be at Dover
Begar, and me be at Greenwish, tree toder legge pishaw.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: A poxe upon your legges, ile no more.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ha ha ha, I wod some Ladies were here to laugh
At thee now, you wonot be so rude to meddle with
The Mounsieur in my lodging.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Ile kicke him to death, and bury him in a Base-violl Iackalent.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Iackalent, begar you be Iackenape, if I had my weapon
You durst no affront me, I be as good gentleman, an for
All my fiddle as you, call me a Iacke a de lent.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Raile upon him Mounsieur, Ile secure thee, ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Because your leg have de poc, or someting dat make
Em no vell, and friske, you make a foole of a Mounsieur.
My Lord use me like Gentleman, an I care no rush for
You, be desperate, kill me, and me complaine to de
King, and teach new dance, galliarde to de gibbet, you
Be hang'd in English fashion. Exit

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Goe, yar'e an impertinent Lord, and I will be reveng'd

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, good Diogenes, come Mounsieur,
You and I wonot part yet.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: My Lord, if you had not beene here, me wod hav
Broken his head with my fiddle.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You might sooner have broke your fiddle, but strike up.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Allei hah boone. They Dance in.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I spie Sir Marmaduke comming after me,
This way Ile take to avoide his tedious questions,
Heele interrupt me, and I ha not finish'd
Things fit for my designe.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Tis Mr Bostocke, little does he thinke
What I am going upon, I feare I shanot
Containe my joyes.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sir you must pardon, I cannot waite
Vpon you now, I ha businesse of much consequence.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I thought to have made the same excuse to you,
For at this present I am so engag'd.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Poore Gentleman how is he beguil'd.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Your nose is wip'd, hum, tis Sr. Marmaduke,
I must salute him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: The Coronell? theres no going backe.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What misfortun's this? but tis no matter,
Noble sir how ist?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: As I could wish noble Mr. Bostocke,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I shannot forbeare jeering these poore things,
They shall be mirth.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: What all met so happily? and how my
Sparkes of honour?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Things so ticle me,
I shall breake out.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: When saw, you our Mistresse Lady Lucina.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: My suite is cold there, Mr. Bostocke carries
The Lady cleane before him.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: No no not, it is Sr. Marmaduke.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I gleane by smiles after Sr. Ambrose.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: None of you see her to day?
I may as soone marry the Moone, and get
Children on her, I see her not this three dayes,
Tis very strange, I was to present my service
This morning.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I cannot tell, but theres small signe of victory,
And yet me thinkes you should not be neglected,
If the Fennes goe forward, and your Iron Mills.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Some are industrious,
And have the excellent skill to cast brasse buttons.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: How will you sell your vineger a pint,
The Patent something sawcie.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Had not you a head once,
Of haire I meane, favours ha glean'd too much,
If Ladies will ha bracelets, let 'em stay
Till the next croppe.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Hum, the very language she us'd to me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Does he jeere him too, nay nay, prethee spare him. ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: You may doe much, and yet I could desire
You were lesse honourable, for though you have
Blood of a deeper crimson, the good Lady
Out of her love could wish you were a thing
Beneath a foote man, and that you had no kindred
But Knights oth' post.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Nay pardon me,
In the humour I am in, I wish, and heartily,
You were a sonne oth' people.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Coronell,
How the devill came he by this?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Vnder the Rose there was a gentleman
Came in at the Wicker, these are tales of which
The Greekes have store, faire hopes Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How came you by this intelligence.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Nay Ile no whispering, what I say to one
Will concerne every man, shee has made
You coxcombes.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: And more then does appeares yet
I had my share.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Thats some comfort, I was afraid.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: But you shall pardon me, Ile conceale
The particulars of her bountifull abuses
To me, let it suffice I know we are all
Ieer'd most abominably, I stood behinde
The hangings when shee sign'd your severall passes,
And had my owne at last worse than the Constables,
That this is true, you shall have more than oath,
Ile joyne wee in revenge, and if you wonot,
I will doe't alone.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Damme her then, till we thinke on something else,
Lets all goe backe, and raile upon her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: We cannot be to bitter, shees a hell Cat.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Dee heare, listen to me our shames are equall,
Yet if we all discharge at once upon her,
We shall but make confusion, and perhaps
Give her more cause to laugh, let us chuse one,
To curse her for us all.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Tis the best way, and if you love me gentlemen,
Engage me, I deserve this favour for my
Discovery, Ile sweare her into hell.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Troth I ha no good veine, I me content.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Gentlemen, noble Coronell as you respect
A wounded branch of the Nobilitie,
Make it my office, she abus'd me most, and if
The devill doe not furnish me with language,
Ile say he has no malice.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: But lets us all together, Ile not be barr'd,
Now and then to enterpose an oath,
As I shall finde occasion.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Youle releeve me
When I take breath, then you may helpe, or you,
Or any to confound her.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Never was witch so tortur'd. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Noble Mr. Freshwater welcome from travell.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: In the next roome sir;
My Lady Rosomond is sitting for her picture,
I presume you will be welcome.

div.stage: He gives Freshwater accesse to the Chamber and returnes.

sp.speaker: Sol,
sp.l: This way,
Honest Gudgin,
How, and the matters abroad, a touch of
Thy travell, what newes.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: First, let me understand the state of things
At home.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: We have little alteration since thou went'st,
The same newes are in fashion,
Onely gentlemen are faine to ramble, and stumble
For their flesh since the breach oth' banke side.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Yet the Viragoes ha not lost their spirit, some on
'Em have challeng'd the field, every day where
Gentlemen have met 'em, oh the dogge-dayes bit
Shreudly, twas a vilanous dead vacation.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Yes, yes, a little sicke oth' stone, she voides some
Every day, but she is now in phisicke,
And may in time recover.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Longer than a Church,
There is no feare while the Merchants have faith;
A little of thy travells, for the time is precious, what
Things have you seene or done since you left England?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: I have not leasure to discourse of particulars, but first
My Mr. and I have runne France through, and through.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Through and through, how is that man?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: Why once forward, and once backward, thats through
And through.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Twas but a cowardly part to runne a Kingdome
Through backeward.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Not with our horses Solomon, not with our horses.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Madam, I did not thinke your Ladiship
Had so little judgement

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: As to let an English man draw
Your Picture, and such rare Mounsieurs in towne.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Oh by no meanes Madam,
They ha not active Pensiles.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You must incourage strangers while you live,
It is the Character of our nation,
We are famous for dejecting our owne countrymen.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why so, tis necessary,
Trust while you live the Frenchman with your legges,
Your faces with the Dutch, if you mislike
Your faces, I meane if it be not sufficiently
Painted, let me commend upon my credit
A pretious workeman to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Not an English man I warrant you,
One that can please the Ladies every way,
You shannot sit with him all day for shaddowes,
He has Regallias, and can present you with
Suckets of foureteene pence a pound, Canary,
Prunellas, Venice glasses, Parmisan,
Sugars, Bologuia, Sausages all from Antwerpe;
But he will make Ollepodredos most incomparably.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I have heard of him by a noble Lady
Told me the tother day, that sitting for
Her picture, shee was stifled with a strange
Perfume of hornes.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: A Butcher told me of 'em, very likely.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: When I have neede
Of this rare Artist I will trouble you
For my directions, leaving this discourse,
How thrives your Catalogue of debtors Signior.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You shannot name me in the list of any
That are behind, beside my debt a purse
For clearing the account.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You are just Madam,
And bountifull, though I came hither with
Simple intention to present my service
It shall be crost. Gudgin remember too,
Her Ladiships name.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: My Cosin has the
Same provision for you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Madam Ile take my leave, Ile finde another
Time to attend my Lady, there's no light,
I cannot abide this fellow. Exit with Gud.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Madam, Master Barker hath some designe
Which he pretends concernes us both.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: My Lord commends him to yee.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The Lord, the fine, the wanton dancing Lord,
The Lord that playes upon the Gitterne, and sings,
Leapes upon tables, and does pretty things,
Would have himselfe commended.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He loves you both, he told me so,
And laughs behind a visard at your frailtie,
He cannot love that way you imagine,
And Ladies of the game are now no miracles.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Although he use to raile thus, yet we have
Some argument to suspect his Lordships tongue
Has beene to liberall.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I finde it too, and blush within to thinke
How much we are deceived, I may be even
With this May-Lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: But does his Lordship thinke
We were so taken with his person.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You wod not, and you knew as much as I.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I ha beene acquainted with his body
Ha knowne his baths and phisicke.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Ist possible, I am sorry now at heart.
I had a good thought on him, hee shall see't,
For I will love some other in revenge,
And presently if any gentleman
Ha but the grace to smile, and court me up too't.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: A buble of Nobilitie, a giddy
Phantasticke Lord, I want none of his titles,
Now in my imaginations he appeares
Ill favoured, and not any part about him
Worth halfe a commendation, wod he were here.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: That I might examine,
And doe my judgement right betweene you two now
How much he would come short, you have an eye
Worth fortie of his, nose of another making;
I saw your teeth ene now compar'd to which,
His are of the complexion of his combe,
I meane his boxe, and will in time be yellower,
And aske more making cleane, you have a shew
Of something on your upper lippe, a Witch
Has a Philosophers beard to him, his chinne
Has just as many hounds as haires that ever
My eyes distinguish'd yet, you have a body
And unpromising in his slashes, one
May see through him, and for his legges they both
Would but make stuffing for one hansome stocking,
Th'are a Lords I will be sworne, I dote upon him,
I could wish somewhat, but I me sworry sir
To trouble you so much, all happie thoughts
Possesse you. Exit

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: How is this, if I have wit
To apprehend, this Lady does not hate me?
I have profest a cinicke openly,
This language melts, Ile visite her againe.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Sir, I have a small request to you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: If you thinke I have power
Or will to deserve from you any courtesie,
Pray learne to dance.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: At my entreatie sir to dance,
It was the first thing tooke me with his Lordship,
You know not what may follow, fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: What pretends this to dance, theres something in't,
I've reveng'd my selfe already upon my Lord,
Yet deeper with my Lady is the sweeter,
Something must be resolv'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Enough enough of conscience, lets reserve
Part of the mirth to another time, I shall
Meete some other hot worships at the Ball;
Vnlesse their appehension prompt 'em,
Earlier to know their folly in pursuing me.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Madam, the Gentlemen that were here this morning
In single visits are come all together,
And pray to speake with you.

div.stage: Enter Bostocke, Lamount, Coronell, and Travers.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Be confident she shall endure it.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: So so,
How dee Gentlemen, yar'e very wellcome.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Tis no matter for that we doe not come to be
Welcome, neither will we be welcome, speake Mr. Bostocke.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But of our tongues, and in the names of these
Abused gentlemen, and my selfe I spit
Defiance, stand further off, and be attentive,
Weepe or doe worse, repentance wet thy linnen,
And leave no veine for the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: There is no danger Madam, let us heare 'em,
If they scold we two shall be hard enough for 'em,
And they were twenty.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Whose eyes shat fire, and poyson,
Malicious as a Witch, and much more cunning,
Thou that dost ride men.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Worse than the night Mare, let thy tongue be silent.
And take our scourges patiently, thou hast
In thy owne selfe all the ingredients
Of wickednesse in thy sexe, able to furnish
Hell if it were insufficiently provided
With falshood, and shee feind of thy owne making
Circe that charm'd men into swine, was not
So much a Jew as thou art, thou hast made
Vs Asses, dost thou heare?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But it is better we be all made such,
Than any one of us be monstred worse
To be an Oxe thy husband.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Spirit of flesh and blood Ile conjure thee,
And let the devill lay thee on thy backe
I care not.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: That spirit of flesh and blood was well inforc'd.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You thought us animales insensible
Of all your juglings did you Prorsepnie?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And that we lov'd, lov'd with a poxe your phisnomie,
Know we but tried thee Beldam, and thou art
Thy selfe a sonne oth' earth.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Twas a mistake, but she knowes my meaning,
I beginne to be a wearie gentlemen,
Ile breath a while.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Tis time, and that you may
Not want encouragement take that.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: You shall know presently, dare but lift thy voyce
To fright this Lady, or but aske thy pardon,
My sword shall rip thy body for thy part,
And naile it on her threshold, or if you,
The proudest offer but in lookes to justifie
The basenesse of this wretch your soules shall answer't.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Oh impudence unheard, pardon Madam
My tedious silence, the affront grew up
So fast I durst not trust my understanding
That any gentleman could attempt so much
Dishonour to a Lady of your goodnesse;
Was this your project to make me appeare
Guilty of that I hate beyond all sacriledge,
Was it for this you pray'd my company,
You todpoles? tis your presence charmes my sword,
Or they shall quickly pay their forfeit lives,
No Altar could protect 'em.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Was it not his plot to have us raile?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Say, shall I yet be active?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By no meanes,
This is no place for blood, nor shall any cause
Engage to such a danger.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Live to be
Your owne vexations then till you be mad,
And then remove your selfe with your owne garters.
You shannot goe before I know from whose
Braine this proceeded, you are the mirth,
Was ever civill Lady so abus'd
In her owne house by ingratefull horseleeches?
Could your corrupted natures finde no way
But this to recompence her noble favours,
Her courteous entertainements, would any
Heathens done like to you? admit she was
So just to say she could see nothing in you
Worthy her deerer thoughts as to say truth,
How could a creature of her wit and judgement
Not see how poore and miserable things
You are at best? must you impudent
In such a loud, and peremptory manner,
Disturbe the quiet of her thoughts and dwelling
Gentlemen rather hinds scarce fit to mixe,
Vnlesse you mend her manners with her drudges.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This shewes a noblenesse, dost not Scutilla?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Why sir, did not you tell us?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Be gone, least I forget my selfe.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I have a token to remember you
A palsie upon your fingers noble Coronell.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Was this his stratagem? we must be gone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir I must thanke yee, and desire your pardon,
For what has past to your particular.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Ya've more than satisfied my service in
Th'acknowledgement: disdaine cannot provoke
Me to be so insolent.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I can forget your last neglect, if you
Thinke me not too unworthy to expect
Some favour from you.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Why as
As a servant should that is ambitious?
To call you Mistresse, till the happier title
Of wife crowne his desires.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I must confesse,
This has wone much upon me: but two words
To such a bargaine, y'are a gentleman,
Ime confident would adventure for me.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: As farre as a poore life could speake my service.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thats faire and farre enough, I make not any
Exception to your person.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Body enough
I hope to please a Lady

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To that the least, I have estate for both.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Though if hold no comparison with youre,
It keepes me like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: You honour me in this,
Theres hope, if I can take a way that care,
You may be mine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir can you put me in securitie
That you have beene honest?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Beene honest of your body, you are gentlemen,
Out of the warres live lazie, and feede high,
Drinke the rich grape, and in Canary may
Doe strange things, when the wine has wash'd away
Discretion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I doe not urge you for the time to come.
Pray understand, have you beene honest hitherto
And yet because you shannot trouble friends
To be compurgators, Ile be satisfied;
If you will take your owne oath that you are.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yes sir, it will become me to be carefull
Of my health, Ile take your owne assurance,
If you can cleare your body by an oath,
Ile marry none but you, before this gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Your reason why you use me thus?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I wonder you will aske, doe not I heare
How desperate some ha beene, what paine, what phisicke.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: This is a tale of a tubbe Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You rid no match without a shirt, to shew
The complexion of your body, I ha done sir
When you resolue to sweare y'are honest, I
Vow to he yours, your wife: I am not hastie,
Thinke on't, and tell me when we meete againe
Anon, to night, to morrow, when you please;
So farewell noble Coronell, come Scutilla. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Ist come to this? I am jeer'd agen, ist possible
To be honest at these yeeres, a man of my
Complexion, and acquaintance? was ever
A gentleman put to this oath before a this fashion?
If I ha the grace now to forsweare my selfe,
Something may be done, and yet tis doubtfull
Sheele have more trickes, if widdowes be thus coltish,
The devill will have a taske that goes a woing. Exit.

div.head: Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: SVch an affront my Lord, I was asham'd on't,
A meere conspiracie to betray our fames,
But had you seene how poorely they behav'd
Themselves, such carven Knights, a paire of Drone-Bees
Ith' midst o'my vexation, if I could
Forbeare to laugh, I ha no blood in me,
They were so farre from striking that they stood
Like Images, things without life and motion,
Feare could not make so much as their tongue tremble,
Left all to me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: So so, what then did you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: The Lady laugh'd too, and the Coronell
Increas'd his noise, to see how she derided
The poore Knights.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Leave their Character and proceede
To what you did.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You shall pardon me my Lord,
I am not willing to report my selfe,
They and the Lady, and the Coronell
Can witnesse I came on.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: But how came you off cosin? that must commend you.

sp.speaker: Bo,
sp.l: I ha my limbes my Lord, no signe of losse
Of blood you see, but this was fortune, how
The Coronell came of t's uncertaine.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: No, I left him, I thinke tis time.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Vpon my faith my Lord I meant it not,
But wounds fall out some time when the swords in,
These are poore things to bragge on, I ha sav'd my
Selfe you see.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: If it be so Ile call you cosin still, my satinist
Harke you shall beate this fellow.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Shall I my Lord without cause?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He shall give you cause presently, how now
Gum'd taffata.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I pay for what I weare
My sattaine Lord? your Wardrobe does not keepe
Me warme, I doe not runne oth' ticket with
The Mercers wife, and leacher out my debts
At country houses.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Theres something else you doe not.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I doe not use to flatter such as you are,
Whose bodies are so rotten, theyle scarce keepe
Their soules from breaking out, I write no odes
Vpon your Mistresse to commend her postures,
And tumbling in a coach towards Padington,
Whether you hurry her to see the Phesants,
And try what operation the egges have
At your returne, I am not taken with
Your mightie nonsence, glean'd from Heathenish playes,
Which leave a curse upon the Author for 'em,
Though I have studied to redeeme you from
The infection of such bookes, which martyr sence
Worse than an Almanacke.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Excellent Satire,
But lash not on, stop here, or I shall kicke
Your learned worship.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: But doe not, I advise you doe not.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: It will fall heavy o'some body, if your Lordship
Kicke me, I shall not spare your cosin there.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: On that condition what doe you thinke o'that?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Excellently well followed by my troth la,
Heele pitch the barre well, I warrant, he does
So follow his kicke.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Good, right as my legge againe.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Your legge, twas hee that kickt you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Dee thinke I doe not feele it?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Why dee not use your toes then?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What for a merry touch,
A tricke, a turne upon the toe, dee heare sir
Yare good company, but if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Love you? why dee heare sir,
I, I,
What a poxe should any man see in you,
Once to thinke on you? love a squirte?
Shall I tell thee what thou art good for?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Good againe, my Lord observe him, for nothing.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Yes thou wot stop a breach in a mudde wall,
Or serve for a Priapus in the garden to
Fright away crowes, and keepe the corne, beane shatter,
Thou wot.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Or thou wot serve at shrove tide to ha thy legges
Broken with penny trounchens in the streete,
Tis pitty any Cocke should stand the pelting,
And such a Capon unpreferr'd.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Cry mercy y'are a kinsman to the Lord,
A Gentleman of high and mighty blood.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: But cold enough, wonot all this provoke him?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Dost heare? for all this I will undertake
To thrash a better man out of a wench.
That travells with her butter milke to market
Betweene two dorsers, any day oth' weeke,
My twice sod taile of greene fish, I will do't
Or loose, my inheritance, tell me, and doe not stammer,
When wert thou cudgell'd last? what woman beate thee?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Thou art the towne top,
A boy will set thee up, and make thee spinne
Home with an Eeleskinne, do not marry, doe not,
Thy wife will coddle thee, and serve thee up
In plates with Sugar and Rose water to
Him that had the grace to cuckold thee;
And if Pythagoras transmigration
Of soules were true, thy spirit should be tenant
To a horse.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: A switch and spurre would doe some good upon you,
Why dost thou enterfare, get the grincomes, goe,
And straddle like a gentleman that wod
Not shame his kindred, but what doe I
Lose time with such a puppie?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Well, goe thy wayes Ile justifie thy wit
At my owne perill.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I would speake with you,
Be not too busie with your Lordships legges,
Ile tell you somewhat.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I bestow'd
A visite on the Ladies which you wot on,
They have their wits still, and resolve to keepe 'em,
They wonot hang themselves for a young Lord,
Nor grow into consumption, other men
Have eyes, and nose, and lippes, and hansome legges too:
So fare you well Lord, my I left your kicke
With your cosin buy buy otter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Very well.
But harke you cosin Bostocke, you have a minde
And modest constitution, I expected
You wod have lifted up your legge.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To kicke him,
Why, and you wod ha given a thousand pound,
I could not do't for laughing, beside,
He was your friend my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Did you spare him
For that consideration?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Howsoever,
What honour had it beene for me to quarrell?
Or wit indeede, if every man should take
All the abuses that are meant, great men
Would be laughed at, some fooles must ha their jests,
Had he beene any man of blood or valour,
One that profes'd the sword, such as the Coronell,
Lesse provocation would ha made me active.

div.stage: Enter Sr. Ambrose, and Sr. Marmaduke.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: The Eagles takes no Flies, is that it, how now
Sir Ambrose, and my honor'd friend Sr. Marmaduke?
You are strangers.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Now shall I be put too't, this taking will undoe me?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Prethee tell me? is the Coronell alive still?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Alive my Lord, yes yes, hee's alive.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Did your Lordship thinke absolutely he was dead?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: No my Lord,
He is very well, but twas your kinsemans fortune.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: To have a blow, a boxe oth' eare.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: With his fist, and an indifferent round one.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Yes, yes he did strike me, I could ha told you that,
But wherefore did he strike, aske 'em that.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: If you would know my Lord, he was our orator
To raile upon the Lady for abusing us,
Which I confesse he did with lung and spirit,
Which in the conclusion, the Coronell
Stroke him toth' ground.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: He did so tis a truth.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Take it: he gave it me my Lord, I asked not for it.
But tis not yet reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A little, but the place protected him.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now since you had the greatest burden in
The affront.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Right, wo wod know whether your resolution
Be first, to question him, for our cause appeares
Subordinate, and may take breath till you
Ha call'd him to account.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I proclaime nothing,
And make no doubt the Coronell will give me
Satisfaction like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: We are answer'd, and take our leave my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: We shall meete at the Ball anon gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Your Lordships servants: now to our designe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: My Lord I take my leave too.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Not yet cosin, you and I ha not done.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You have cosen'd me too much.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Thou most unheard of coward,
How dare you bost relation to me?
Be so impudent as to name, or thinke upon me,
Thou staine to honour, honour? th'art beneath
All the degrees of basenesse: quit thy father,
Thy suppos'd one, and with sufficient testimony,
Some Servingman leapt thy mother, or some Iuggler
That conjures with old bones, some womans tailor,
When he brought home her petticoate, and tooke measure
Of her lose body, or Ile cullice thee
With a bottome.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Be so baffoul'd?
In presence of your Mistresse, tis enough
To make the blood of all thou knowest suspected,
And Ile ha satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: For using of my name in Ordinaries,
Ith' list of other whom you make your priviledge,
To dominere, and winne applause sometimes
With Tapsters, and thread-beare Tobacco Merchants,
That worship your gold lace, and ignorance
Stand bare, and bend their hammes, when you belch out
My Lord, and tother cosin in a Baudihouse,
Whom with a noyse you curse by Iacke and Tom,
For failing you at Fishstreete, or the Still-yard.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Not against your honour, but you shall see.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And vexe my eyes to looke on such a Land-rat,
Were all these shames forgotten, how shall I
Be safe in honour with that noble Lady,
To whom I sinne fully commended thee,
Though twere not much, enough to make her thinke
I am as base as thou art, and the Coronell,
And all that have but heard thee call me cosin,
What cure for this you Malt-worme? oh my soule
How it does blush to know thee, bragging puppie,
Dee heare me thunder, and lightning, what
Nobilitie my predecessors bosted,
Or any man from honours stocke descended;
How many Marquesses and Earles are numbred
In their great family? what coates they quarter,
How many battells our forefathers fought?
Tis poore, and not becomming perfect gentry
To build their glories at their fathers cost,
But at their owne expense of blood or vertue,
To raise them living monuments, our birth
Is not our owne act, honour upon trust,
Our ill deedes forfeit, and the wealthy summes
Purchas'st by others fame or sweate, will be
Our staine, for we inherit nothing truely
But what our actions make us worthy of;
And are you not a precious gentleman,
Thou art not worth my steele, redeeme this love
Some generous way of undertaking, or
Thou shalt be given up to boyes, and ballets,
The scorne of footeman, a disgrace more blacke
Than bastard, goe to the Coronell.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: But now I thinke ont twill be necessarie,
That first you right my honour with the Lady,
You shall carry a letter, you will do't?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Such another conjuring will make me
Beleeve I am illigitimate indeede,
This came first keeping company with the blades,
From whom I learnt to roare and runne away:
I know tis a base thing to be a coward,
But every man is not borne to be a Hercules,
Some must be beate that others may be valiant. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Rosomond, and Honoria whispering, Sr. Marmaduke, and Sr. Ambrose following.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Let it be so, they will else be troublesome.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This cannot I hope displease you Lady, tis
No new affection I protest, although
This be the first occasion I tooke
To expresse it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You did ill in the impression,
Although your bashfulnesse would not permit you
To speake in your owne cause, you might have sent
Your meaning, I can make a shift to read
A scurvie hand, but I shall tell you sir.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ist possible your heart hath beene tormented
In loves flame, and I the cause.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Your beauty hath the power
To melt a Cithians bosome, those divine
Beames would make soft the earth, when rugged Winter
Hath seal'd the cranies up with frost, your eye
Will make the frigid region temperate,
Should you but smile upon't: account it then
No wonder if it turne my brest to ashes.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I see you are in love by your mention,
And cause I pitty a gentleman should lose
His passion Ile acquaint you with a secret.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What misfortune twas
You did not first apply your selfe to her
That can reward your love, and hath a heart
Spacious to entertaine you; she does love you
Vpon my knowledge strangely, and so
Commends you in your absence.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Say you so Lady?
Pardon I beseech you the affection
I profest to your Ladiship, twas but
A complement, I am sorry I protest.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Oh tis excus'd sir, but I must tell you,
Perhaps you wonot finde her now so tractable
Vpon the apprehension she was slighted;
But to prescribe you confidence were to
Suspect your art, and bold discretion.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Tis as I tell you sir, no Lady in
The world can speake more praises of your body?
Shee knowes not yet your minde.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And yet because she saw your complements
Directed so unhappily to me,
I know not how youle finde her on the sudden,
But tis not halfe an houre since you possest
The first place in her thoughts.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Shall I presume,
You will excuse the love I did present
Your Ladiship? it was not from my heart,
I hope you will conceive so.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Tis sufficient
That you recant no more neglect.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Be you so too; Ile justifie thou shalt
Have cause.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: To wonder at you, whats your meaning sir?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sweete Lady,
What thoughts make sad your brow? I have observ'd
Your eyes shoote clearer light.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd,
I am not melancholy.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Be for ever banish'd
The imagination of what can happen
To cloud so rare a beautie, y'are in love.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: In love, who told you so?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: But thats no wonder,
We all may love, but you have onely power
To conquer where you place affection, and triumph ore your wishes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I love you, y'are strangely sir mistaken,
Put your devices on some other Lady,
I ha beene so farre from my affection to you,
That I ha laboured I confesse to unsettle
The opinion of my Lady Rosomond,
Who I confesse loves you, and that extreamely.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How? she love me? then I ha made fine worke.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What cunning shee is mistresse of to hide
Her strange affections, or what power she has,
She does flie into your armes I know not.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Are you so dull?
Why, this was but to try your constancie,
I have heard her sweare you are the proprest Knight,
The very Adonis: why, she has got your picture
And made it the onely saint within her closet,
I blush at your credulitie.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Ist e'ne so?
I have undone my selfe with her already,
Pardon me gentle Madam, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We are reliev'd, Enter Mounsieur.
Mounsieur Le Friske.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Tres humbla serviter Madam,
Me sweate with de hast to waite upon your Ladiships;
I pray give me do leve dispatch presently,
For I must figaries to be done.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Gentlemen let your passions breath a while,
A little musicke may correct the errour,
And you may finde your selves.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: With all my heart Sr. Marmaduke lets helpe
To exercise the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: And begar noting in de world mor profet
Your body den de motion all a more de France.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Ha de friske you jumpe upon my name, and
Begar you have my nature to de right, hey, and
All de world is but friske.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Hah, Mounsieur Madam aller, They Dance.
Forboone, tres excellent begar, so I crave your patience
Madam, gentlemen, you be at de Ball, mofoy you
See dat was never in dis world.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: What doe you thinke dat is, me tell you, begar
You see me play de part of de Cupid.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Begar French Cupid, why? dere is no love like
De French love, dat is Cupid, love is hot, and de
French is hot

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: How comes it to passe that you are to play Cupid Moun.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: My Lord give me command me have device, & de masque
For de Ladies, and me no trust little Iacknape to play
Young Cupid but my selfe.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Cupid is a childe, you have a beard Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Me care not de haire for dat, begar de little god may have
De little beard, Venus his moder have de mole, and Cupid
Her shild may have the blacke mussell.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But Mounsieur, we read Cupid was faire, and
You are blacke, how will that agree?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Cupid is faire, and Mounsieur is blacke, why Mounsieur
Is blacke den, and Cupid is faire, what is dat? a faire
Lady love de servant of the blacke
Complexion de ban eur, the colour is not de mush,
Vulcan was de blacke Smith, and Cupid may be de
Blacke gentleman his sonne legitimate.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Tis de way to make Cupid the boy no bastard.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: But doe you no publish this invention, me meete you
At de Ball armed with quiver, and de bow.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: You wonot shoote us, I hope youle spare our hearts.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Begar me shit you if me can, and your arts shall
Bleed one, two, tree, gallowne adieu Madame
Serviter gentlemen tresemble.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Adieu Mounsieur, now Madam with your favour,
I must renew my suite.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Yad better buy a new one,
Nay then we shall be troubled. Exit.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Youle withdraw,
Ile follow you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Come, come I know you love me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: You may enlarge your folly my deare knight,
But I have pardoned you for love already.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This shannot serve your turne, I came hither
Not to be jeered, and one of you shall love me. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Bostocke, Lady Lucina and Scutilla.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Most gracious Madam, my cosin your Lord Loveall
Commends himselfe in blacke and white.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Dee thinke tis from my selfe.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: You might ha dont in blacke and blew.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Scutilla how does thy poore soule, thou
Hast no husband nor children to commend me to.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: The poore soule's well, I hope your body is
Recover'd, dos not your left cheeke burne still,
We ha so talkt on you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am sorry any gentleman that has relation to me should
Be so forgetfull of your honor, & his own, but though he have
Forfited opinion, let me continue innocent in your thoughts?
I have sent you a small jewell to expiate my offence for
Commending him, I expect your Ladiship at the Ball,
Where you shall make many happie to kisse your hand,
And in their number the true admirer of your vertue,
My Lord is honourable.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Nay faith my Lord is right, I ha not met
The Coronell since you know when.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: You ha more reason to remember.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I would be so bold to aske you a question.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In the meane time give me leave, we are none
But friends, I know y'are valliant.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: No, no, you doe not know't, but I know my selfe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But will you answer me? why did not you strike him agen?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But blood are not a like, termes were not even,
If I had kill'd him there had beene an end.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Right Madam, but if he had wounded me,
He might ha kill'd, heaven knowes how many.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: D'ee not conceive it? so many drops of mine,
So many gentlemen, nay more, who knowes
Which of these might ha beene a Knight, a Lord.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Princes came from the blood,
And should I hazard such a severation
Against a single life, tis not I feare
To fight with him by these hills, but what wise gamester
Will venture a hundred pound to a flaw'd sixe pence?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And he were ten Coronells, Ile not endure his company,
Sweete Lady, you and Ile retire.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: He should not seeke me then.

sp.speaker: Sc.
