sp.p: He should rather hardly find you, Ime your servant. exit

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I was wishing for you sir,
Your judgement of these Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: They were a Lords, sent me for a token,
You cannot chuse but know him, the Lord Loveall.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: So, so, so, I am like to speede.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is not he a pretty gentleman?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: And you are sure hee's honest?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: As Lords goe now adayes that are
In fashion;
But cry you mercy, you ha put me in minde,
I did propound a businesse to you sir.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: And I came prepar'd to answer you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Tis very well, Ile call one to be a witnesse.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: That was not I remember in our Covenant,
You shannot neede.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ile fetch you a booke to sware by

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Let it be Venus and Adonis then,
Or Ovids wanton Elieges, Aristotles
Problemes, Guy of Warwicke, or Sr. Beavis,
Or if there be a Play Booke you Love better,
Ile take my oath upon your Epilogue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Y'are very merry, well, sweare how you please.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: In good time,
You doe expect now I should sweare Ime honest?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yes sir, and tis no hard condition,
If you reflect upon my promise.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To marry you, which act must make you Lord
Of me and my estate, a round possession,
Some men have gone to hell for a lesse matter.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: But I wonot be damn'd for twenty thousand
Such as you are, and every one a million,
And I the authoritie of a Parliament
To marry wo'yee all, I wod not buy
This flesh now I ha sworne.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I thinke so Coronell,
Blesse me? twenty thousand wives, two'd nere
Come to my turne, and you'd not live to give
The tithe benevolence.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: They would finde Pages, fooles, or Gentlemen-Vshers.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then upon the matter,
You being not willing sir to take your oath,
I may be confident you are not honest.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Why looke upon me Lady, and consider
With some discretion what part about me
Does looke so tame you should suspect me honest,
How old dee thinke I am?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Some ith' world doubted me not so much,
At thirteene I was ever plumpe and forward,
My drie Nurse swore at seven, I kist like one
Of five and twenty, setting that a side,
Whats my profession?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: So examine a whole army, and finde one
Souldier that hates a hansome woman, we cannot march
Without our bagge and baggages, and is it possible,
When we come home where womens pride, and all
Temptation to wantonesse abounds
We should lose our activitie?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: When we have our pay,
We vow no chastitie till we marry, Lady
Tis out of fashion indeede with gentlemen
To be honest, and of age together tis sufficient,
We can provide to take our pleasures too,
Without infection, a sound body is
A treasure I can tell you, yet if that
Would satisfy you, I should make no scruple
To sweare, but otherwise you must pardon us
As we must pardon you.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Yes you, as if you Ladies had not your fagaries,
And martiall discipline, as well as we,
Your outworkes, and redoubts, your court of guard,
Your centries, and perdues, sallies, retreates,
Pasties, and stratagems, women are all honest,
Yes, yes, exceeding honest; let me aske you
One question, Ile not put you to your oath,
I doe allow you Hide-Parke, and Spring-Garden,
You have a recreation called the Ball,
A device transported hither by some Ladies
That affect Tenice, what dee play a set?
Theres a foule racket kept under the line,
Strange words are bandied, and strange revells Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But if men had no more wit, and honesty,
They wod let fall their stings on something else,
This is discours'd, but when Corantaes faile,
Or newes at ordinaries, when the phlegmaticke Dutch
Ha tane no Fisher-boates, or our Cole-ships land
Safe at New-Castle, y'are fine gentlemen,
But to conclude of that we met for your honesty,
Not justified by an oath, as I expected,
Is now suspended, will you sweare yet.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Why, I thought you had beene a Christian? widdow
Have I not told you enough, you may meete one
Will forfeit his conscience, and please you better,
Some Silke-worme oth' Cittie, or the Court,
There be enough will sweare away their soule
For your estate, but I have no such purpose,
The warres will last I hope.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So so, Scutilla. Enter Scutilla.
You were present when I promis'd the Coronell,
To be his wife upon condition.
He could secure my opinion by his oath,
That he was honest, I am bound in honour
Not to goe backe, y ave done it, I am yours sir,
Be you a witnesse to this solemne contract.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Are you in earnest Lady, I ha not sworne.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You have given better truth,
He that can make this conscience of an oath
Assures his honesty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Whats past
I question not, if for the time to come
Your love be vertuous to me.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Most religious,
Or let me live the Souldiers dishonour,
And die the scorne of gentlemen, I ha not
Space enough in my heart to entertaine thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is not this better than swearing?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Now I may call you husband?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: No title can more honour me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If please you Ile shew you then my children.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ha sixe that call me mother.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The elder may want softnesse to acknowledge you,
But some are young enough, and may be counsell'd
To aske your blessing, does this trouble you?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Trouble me? no, but it is the first newes Lady
Of any children.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay, they are not like
To be a burden to us, they must trust
To their owne portions left 'em by their father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But of my estate, I cannot keepe
Any thing from 'em, and I know you are
So honest, you'd not wish me wrong the Orphans,
Tis but sixe thousand pound in money Coronell
Among them all, beside some trifling plate
And jewels worth a thousand more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Ioynture will be firme to us, two hundred
Per annum.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Is it so? and that will keepe
A Country house, some halfe a dozen Cowes,
We shall ha cheese and butter-milke, one horse
Will serve me, and your man to ride to markets.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Canst be content to live ith' country Coronell?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: And watch the Pease, looke to the Hay, and talke
Of Oates and Stubble, I ha beene brought up too't,
And for a need can thrash.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Ith yeere, beside my skill in farrowing pigs,
Oh tis a holsome thing to hold the plough,
And wade up to the calfe ith' dirty furrowes,
Worse than sleeping in a trench, or quagmire,
You ha not heard me whistle yet.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Why? theres it, shee does counterfeit, well Lady,
Be you in jeast or earnest, this is my
Resolution Ile marry you, and y'ad forty children,
And not a foote of land to your Ioynture, heaven
Will provide for, and we doe our endeavours,
Where be the children, come how many boyes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: As many as can get sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No more.
Since y'are so noble, know I tried your patience,
And now I am confirm'd, my estate is yours
Without the weight of children or of debts,
Love me, and I repent not.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Saist thou so?
I wod we had a Priest here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There remaines to take away one scruple.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have none, tis your doubt sir,
And ere we marry you shall be convinc'd
Some mallice has corrupted your opinion
Of that we call the Ball.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will intreate your company to night,
Where your owne eyes shall leade you to accuse
Or vindicate our fames.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Madam, Mr. Bostocke
Expects within.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You shall be reconcil'd to him.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: With Bostocke willingly, then toth Ball,
Which for your sake I dare not now suspect,
Where union of hearts such Empire brings,
Subjects methings are crown'd as we as Kings. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Mounsieur and servants with perfume.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: BOne for bone here a little, dere a little more, my
Lord hire dis house of the citie Merchent, begar
It smell musty, and he will have all sweete for de
Ladies, perfume, perfume every corner presently
For dere is purpose to make all smoke anon
Begar; Enter Lady Rosomond and Honoria.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Hee waite on you presently Mounsieur de Freshwater.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Mounsieur Le Friske these Ladies were pleas'd
To command my attendance hither.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Welcome to de Ball, par ma foy
You pardon Mounsieur, I have much trouble
In my little head, I can no stay to
Complement, a vostre service. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: In all my travells, I have not seene a more
Convenient Structure.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Now you talke of your travells Signior, till my Lord
Come you shall doe us a speciall favour to
Discourse what passages you ha seene abroad.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Were you ever abroad before Signior.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I hardly ever was at home, and yet
All countries lost wiseman are his owne?
Did you never travell Ladies,

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: We are no Ladies errant, tis enough
For such as you, that looke for State employment.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Yet there be Ladies ha your languages,
And married to great men prove the better Statesmen.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: We have heard talke of many countries.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: And you may heare talke, but give me the man
That has measur'd 'em, talkes but talke.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Have you seene a fairer Citie than London?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: To what it will be a hundred yeares hence.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I have heard much talke of Paris.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: You have beene there I me sure. Enter Lord.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I tell you Madame, I tooke shipping at
Gravesend, and had no sooner past
The Cantons, and Grissons, making some stay
In the Valtoline, but I came to Paris a pretty
Hamlet, and much in the scituation like Dunstable,
Tis in the Province of Alcontora, some three leagues
Distant from Civill, from whence we have our Oringes.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I have heard Civill is in Spaine.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You may heare many things,
The people are ciuill that live in Spaine, or there
May be one towne like another, but if Civill
Be not in France, I was never at Civill in my life.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Doe not I know Paris, it was built by the yongest Son
Of King Priam, and was call'd by his name, yet some
Call it Lutetia, because the gentlewomen there
Play so well upon the Lute.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Here I observ'd many remarkeable buildings, as the
Vniversitie, which some call the Loure, where the
Students made very much of me, and carried me
To the Beare-garden, where I saw a play on the
Banke-side, a very pretty Comedy call'd Martheme,
In London.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But there be no such Comedians as we have here,
Yet the women are the best Actors, they play
Their owne parts, a thing much desir'd in England
By some Ladies, Innes a Court Gentlemen, and others,
But that by the way.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I had staid longer there, but I was offended with a
Villanous sent of Onions, which the winde brought from
St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Onions wod make you sleepe well.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But the sent tis not to be endured, I smelt
On 'em when I came to Rome, and hardly scap'd the
Inquisition fort.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Were you at Rome too Signior.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Tis in my way to Venice, Ile tell you Madam I was very
Loth to leave their country.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Right, for I had a very good Inne, where mine Host
Was a notable good fellow, and a Cardinall.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Oh the catches we sang, and his wife a pretty woman,
And one that warmes a bed one oth' best in Europe.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Did you ever heare the like.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Right, had a shrew'd pate, and his eares were something
O'th longest, for one upon the oath of a w
Walloune that from Spaine to the Low-
Countries, and the other from Lapland into Germany.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: A parlous head, and yet loving to his guests,
As mine host Bankes, as red in the gills, and as merry
A but anger him, and hee sets all Christendome
Together by the eares, well shortly after I left
France, and sayling along the Alpes, I came to
Lombardy, where I left my cloke, for it was very
Hot travelling, and went a Pilgrim to Rome
Where I saw the Tombs, and a Play in Pompeys
Theater, here I was kindely entertain'd by an anchorite,
In whose chamber I lay, and drinke Cider.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: What should I trouble you with many stories? from hence
I went to Naples, a soft kinde of people, and cloth'd
In silke, from thence I went to Florence from whence we
Have the art of working custards, which we call
Florentines, Millan a rich state of
Haberdashers, Permount, where I had excellent Venison,
And Padua, famous for the pads, or easie saddles
Which our physitions ride upon, and first brought from
Thence when they commenst Doctor.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I see little in Mantua, beside dancing upon the ropes,
Onely their strong beere, better than any I
Ever drunke at the Trumpet, but Venice of all
The Champion Countries, do not mistake they are the
Valiantest gentlemen under the Sunne.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: O the Catazaners we turn'd there.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Two or three magnifico's grandees of the State,
We tickled 'em in the very Pialto, by the same
Token two or three English spies told us they had laine
Leger three moneths to steale away the Piatzo, and ship
It for Covent. Garden, a pretty fabricke and building
Vpon the but I was compell'd to make
Short stay here by reason of the Dukes Concubines
Fell in love wee me, gave me a ring of his, out of
A solide Diamonde, which afterwards I lost washing my
Hands in the salt water.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You should ha fish'd fort, and as good lucke as
She that found her wedding ring in the
Haddocks belly.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: No, there was no staying, I tooke post presently
For Genoa, and from thence to Madrill, and so to
The Netherlands.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: And how sped you among the Dutch?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why, we were drunk every day together, they get their
Living by it.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: And making bargaines in their tippling,
The Iewes are innocent, nay the devill himselfe
Is but a Dunce to 'em, of whose trade they are.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: They fish, they fish still, who can helpe it, they
Have nets enough, and may catch the Province
In time then let the Kingdomes looke about 'em,
They can't be idle, and they have one advantage
Of all the world, theyle ha no conscience to trouble
'Em, I heard in whispered they want butter, they have
A Designe to charme the Indies, and remove their
Darie, but that as a secret, shall goe no further;
I caught a surfet of Bore in Holland, upon my
Recovery I went to Flushing, where I met with a hansome
Froe, with whom I went to Middleborough, by the
And lest her drunke at Roterdam, there I tooke
Shipping againe for France, from thence to Dover,
From Dover to Gravesend, from Gravesend to Queene-
Hive, and from thence to what I am come to.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And noble Signior you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I hope he did not over-heare me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I am much honor'd Ladies in your presence.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Absence had beene a sinne my Lord where you
Were pleas'd to invite. Enter Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Fie, fie, my Lord give me one eare.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Interrupt me no more good Moursieur.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Mounsieur La Friske, a word, a word, I beseech you,
No excuser moy. Exit Fresh. and Moun.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Have you thought Ladies of your absent servant?
Within whose heart the civill warre of love,

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: May end in a soft peace.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: We had armies too my Lord, of wounded thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And are you agreed to which I must devote
My loving service, and which is wisest, fairest,
Is it concluded yet?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You did propound
A hard Province, and we could not
Determine as you expected, but if
Your flame be not extinct, we have devis'd
Another way.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: You make my ambition happy,
And indeede I was thinking twas impossible
That two such beauties should give place to either,
And I am still that humble notary
To both your loves.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Then this we have made lots,
That what we cannot, fate may soone divide,
And we are fixt to obey our destinie,
There is but two, one and your wishes guide you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And will you satisfie my chance.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We should
Be else unjust.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Your hat my Lord,
If you vouchsafe the favour?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Dare you expose your head to the ayre so long?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: That draw which quickly tell how much I love you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: So, so now let me see, I commend your device,
Since I am uncapable of both,
This is a way indeede, but your favour.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Lets have faire play my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: What foole is he?
That having the choise of Mistresses will be
Confinde to one, and rob himselfe, I am yet
The favorite of both these, is no policy,
I could make shift with both abed.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: In troth, and so I am, and in the minde
I am in, will give my selfe no cause toth' contrary,
Dee see? Ile draw you both.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: How? both.
You cannot otherwise be reconcil'd,
Ile be content to marry one, and doe
Service to th' others peticote, I must tell you,
I am not without president.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Within the name of Venus, ha a blanke,
By this light nothing, neither name nor marke.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Tis quickly solv'd,
Your Lordship was too confident,
We never were at such a losse my Lord,
As with the hazard of our wit or honour
To court you with so desperate affection.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: By our example know, some Ladies may
Commend, nay love a gentleman, and yet
Be safe in their owne thoughts, and see as farre
As modesty, and honour will allow us,
We are still servants to your Lordship,

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Say so? why looke you Ladies that you may perceive,
How I can be temperate too; first, I thanke you
Heartily, and to recompence your wit;
Present another Lottery, you shannot
Suspect I have a thought that will betray
Your innocence to scandall, let me intreate
You take your chance too, this for you Madam,
And this is left your fortune, doe me honour
To weare these paire of Iewells for my sake,
So with a confidence of your happy pardon,
To what is past hereafter I shall pay
To your true vertues, better service then
So unnecessary trialls.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And to shew
We are not coy my Lord, weele weare your Iewell.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And be their ornament.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: All happinesse to your Lordship,
Your cruells are not full set noble Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Your presence will so ne make us active, Madam
I was bold.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: She has your Diamond my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Nay, nay, we are friends, are
We not Madam?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: The Coronell too has given me satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: As much as I desir'd, and heres my hand,
While I can draw a sword command me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To put it up agen, all friends, all friends,
A poxe a quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Kisse my hand, kisse my noble Ladies here.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Why is Musicke silent all this while?
Has it no voyce to bid these Ladies welcome?

div.stage: A golden Ball descends, Enter Venus and Cupid.

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: Come Boy now draw thy powerfull Bow,
Here are Ladies hearts enough
To be transfixt, this meeting is
To ruffle Ladies, and to kisse,
These are my Orgies, from each eye,
A thousand wanton glances flie;
Lords, and Ladies of the Game,
Each brest be full of my owne flame:
Why shootes not Cupid? these are all,
Met in honour of my Ball,
Which Paris gave to Ida hill,
Ile maintaine these revells still:
Why stayes Cupid all this while.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: These are none of Venus traine,
No sparke of this Lacivious fire,
Dwells in their bosomes, no desire,
But what doth fill Diana's breast,
In their modest thoughts doe rest.
Venus this new festivall,
Shall be still Diana's Ball:
A chaste meeting ever here,
Seeke thy votaries other where.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: You're chast indeede, doe not we know,
You to your sweete-heart nightly goe,
Envying one is not kist, no you
On his face but let fall dew;
Some may wonder what doth ayle,
Your lippes but kisses made them pale
Me thinkes the Moone should blush,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I doe
Some times, but tis for such as you:
Then hide my selfe within a mist,
For shame to see thee clipt and kist.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Draw Cupid, shall thy mother be
Brand by a Huntresse, let me see
I want one shaft.

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.l: Moder not so,
You may quickly breake my bow,
Here Diana doth command,
My Bow is frozen to my hand,
Beside, the Ladies breasts are here,
Such proofes against my shafts I feare,
Each arrow would to our disgrace,
Breake, or rebound in my owne face;
Moder, flie hence or you will be,
If youle stay, made as chaste as she.

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: Can her Magicke charme them so,
Then tis time that Venus goe
To seek her owne more choice delight,
Against my will, enjoy this night.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Cupid if you meane to stay,
Throw your licensious shafts away,
Then you are Love, then be embrac't,
Love is welcome while he's chast;
Now some other straine to show,
What pleasures to this night we owe. A Dance.

div.stage: Enter Barker, like a Satyre Dancing.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: My Lord, my Ladies, will you see a Monster,
I have not met such another in all my travailes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What have we here a Satyre.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Wonder that a Satyre can
Put off wildnesse and turne man,
Love, such miracles can doe,
But this owes it selfe to you
Bright Lady.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Keepe the goblin from me Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: No more, the Cynicke, I protest
You have converted me.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I am the man you did incourage Madam
To learne to dance, I shall doe better shortly,
Your love will perfect me, and make me soft,
And smooth as any Reveller.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, my Love, I am not mad to love a Satyre,
For that's thy best condition, judgement all,
How scurvily this civility shewes in him.
Faith raile, and keepe your humour, still it shewes excellent,
Does he not become the beast,
The Lords allow you pension.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: You are a Witch, Ile justifie it, and there is not
One honest thought among the whole Sex of you,
Dee laugh, loose witted Ladies, there are not
In hell such furies, that's a comfort yet
To him that shall goe thither, he shall have
Lesse torment after death then he findes here.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Your wit has got the squirte too, Ile traduce
Your Ball for this, and if there be a post,
That dares write mischiefe, looke to be worse
Then executed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He will come to himselfe agen, when he hath purg'd
Freshwater.

div.stage: Enter Sir Stephen, and Sir Lionell.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Madam your servants begge this favour from you.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: That since your resolutions will admit
No change of hearts you will not publish how
We ha beene jeer'd.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Not jeer'd, but you came on so desperate.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We love our owne when we preserve,
Gentlemens honour.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Mercy and silence as you are honourable.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why if I must gentlemen, you imagine I ha beene
At Venice, but I staid at Gravesend
All this Summer expecting a winde, and finding it
So uncertaine, will deferre the voyage till the Spring,
I am not the first whom the windes, and seas have crost.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Then you have crost no Sea?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: If you please, Ile require
But my principall, and for your good company,
Ile stay at home for good, and all to be merry.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay, nay, you shall goe your voyage,
We wod not have you lose the benefit
Of travell, when you come home, you may summon
Your debters by a drumme, and shewing your bagge
Of certificates.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Receive your money when you can get it, and be
Knighted.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I thanke you gentlemen, I am in a way now,
I have sold my land, and put out my mony
To live I see my heart wonot dance to night,
I may to Gravesend in the morning,
I can be but pickled in salt water, and Ile
Venture one drowning to be reveng'd
Agen, agen, set, set.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What thinke you of all this?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: To my wishes, an innocent, and generous recreation.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Ladies and Gentlemen, now a banquet waites you,
Be pleas'd to accept, twill give you breath and then,
Renew our Revells, and toth' Ball agen.
